Some Views On Spirit
There was a time when Hopkins was steeped in "good" collegiate tradition. Freshmen were required to wear beanies,
army ties,' black socks; and access to Gilman Hall for the Frosh
was only through the tunnel entrance. Just as the tunnel is now
about to fade into oblivion, these childish manifestations of
school spirit were forgotten as the University grew from adolescence into maturity.
No doubt there was an enthusiastic school spirit in the days
of class yells like "... fatta, dikka, foo! Hopkins! Hopkins!
Nineteen two!"; but a return of the present Hopkins community
to the "beanie" method of building school spirit would, we feel,
be contrary to what the University has come. to stand for.
These superficial, physical displays may help to instill a
sense of belonging and pave the way for a deeper, abstract "enthusiastic loyalty" to the University; but they are at best only a
beginning. The essence of the spirit at this University seems
to he based on a respect for the higher ideals toward which its
men strive, rather than the transitory whims of immature
individuals. Perhaps the most important factors in forming This
spirit are the Customs, the Athletic Program, and the Gentleman's Code.
Outlined,on page 109 of the Handbook are the few customs
of the University; they are simple. For example; Leaving a class
if the professor does not appear within five minutes, and rising
at any gathering when the President of the University is introduced.
All Freshmen are introduced to learn and observe these
customs, yet the front door of Gilman listed in the series of
customs a,s reserved for seniors, is now a thruway, the Gilman
Memorial room is an extension of smoke alley, and the seal
embedded in the floor of the Gilman foyer is trod upon by professors, students and visitors alike. There are sound traditions
behind all of these observances, they manifest a respect for the

Some Views On Spirit
There was a time when Hopkins was steeped in "good" collegiate tradition. Freshmen were required to wear beanies,
army ties,' black socks; and access to Gilman Hall for the Frosh
was only through the tunnel entrance. Just as the tunnel is now
about to fade into oblivion, these childish manifestations of
school spirit were forgotten as the University grew from adolescence into maturity.
No doubt there was an enthusiastic school spirit in the days
of class yells like "... fatta, dikka, foo! Hopkins! Hopkins!
Nineteen two!"; but a return of the present Hopkins community
to the "beanie" method of building school spirit would, we feel,
be contrary to what the University has come. to stand for.
These superficial, physical displays may help to instill a
sense of belonging and pave the way for a deeper, abstract "enthusiastic loyalty" to the University; but they are at best only a
beginning. The essence of the spirit at this University seems
to he based on a respect for the higher ideals toward which its
men strive, rather than the transitory whims of immature
individuals. Perhaps the most important factors in forming This
spirit are the Customs, the Athletic Program, and the Gentleman's Code.
Outlined,on page 109 of the Handbook are the few customs
of the University; they are simple. For example; Leaving a class
if the professor does not appear within five minutes, and rising
at any gathering when the President of the University is introduced.
All Freshmen are introduced to learn and observe these
customs, yet the front door of Gilman listed in the series of
customs a,s reserved for seniors, is now a thruway, the Gilman
Memorial room is an extension of smoke alley, and the seal
embedded in the floor of the Gilman foyer is trod upon by professors, students and visitors alike. There are sound traditions
behind all of these observances, they manifest a respect for the
University, its first president, and its seniors—failure to observe
.ms is tantamount to showing disrespect for the University.

The athletic policy is such that a student is primarily motivated to play for the sport rather than the idolized admiration of
his fellow students. The athlete is a student first, and as much
a gentleman a-s a sportsman.
The Honor Code is the proudest tradition we can boast;
on its success hinge the very ideals of the University. If we
do not abide by it we jeopardize our positions in a community
that assumes us to be gentlemen and scholars, in fact we endanger the underlying spirit of an academic community.
The text of the Gentleman's Code is included here in its
entirety because we feel that it is the embodiment of the spirit
unique at the Hopkins.
• The Johns Hopkins Honor System is the self-imposed moral code of a community of gentlemen. It
exists, in this community, to guarantee high standards
of conduct, to limit membership to persons who are able
and willing to maintain these standards.
The Honor System governs not only conduct in
class and examination rooms, but also those aspects
of behavior among students on the Campus, or at the
location of Campus-sponsored activities, which might in
any way compromise or undermine the present valued
ethical concept of Hopkins men.
An honor system is a privilege resting upon the
clearly perceived merit of its beneficiaries. They must
exercise care in order that no suspicion of evasion or
violation fall upon them.
Since the inception of the Honor Code, all true
Hopkins men have revered and respected it, considering
themselves privileged to abide by its principles.
We do not feel that spirit is lacking at Hopkins, we do feel
that we have a kind of spirit that differs from the "rah rah" feeling so often found in contemporary American colleges. The
spirit here is what might be expected in a truly scholarly environment—we are more than merely pupils, we are students, and we
are more than merely students—we are gentlemen a.s well.
Those who scurry about looking for the Hopkins spirit seem to be
unable to find it because they are looking in the wrong direction.

Taking stock of the major spring sport situation, we see

squad; but promising sophomores will be groomed by next year
to take their places.
